Description: Shoulder and body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater with turn to neck; interior glazed (fired reddish); exterior: band at junction with neck; black-figure decoration consisting of parts of three padded dancers; from left, trace of hair, left arm, shoulder and part of buttock with added red of dancer to left; upper part of bearded central dancer, facing right and extending drinking horn in left hand, right hand extended forward at waist level; traces of red on lower part of garment; at right, upper part of bearded dancer facing left (top of head, left arm, back and legs missing; traces of red on garment), raising right hand to greet central figure.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1924,1201.1155, 1924,1201.1305 and Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA174, and possibly also Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA173. Seeberg states that the vessel was produced by a painter in the Klyka Group. Seeberg, A., Corinthian Komos Vases. London 1971, 54
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.34)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.041) (Phase 1)
